messages: 53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:46): oxygene: yes, during the optimizations the build fails.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:47): there's a couple of files in ffmpeg's lavc (which are codecs) that it does that one.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:47): IBM's xlc IPA does the same, too.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:49): there is no recent Solaris PowerPC port.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (04:49): it'd be more likely to get use than the studio compilers on linux.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (04:49): but that's not really saying so much.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:49): the last one is Solaris 2.5.1, so I doubt it.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (04:50): delewis: he means the opensolaris port, no doubt.

53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:51): I'm specific about that sort of thing, as Solaris is Sun's distribution of OpenSolaris. Considering that it's an OpenSolaris port, Sun has no interest in porting the Sun Studio compilers to it.
b8ac460f16efd92d9e259415a4930199 (04:51): i would laugh a good while if the manage to compile a booteable linux kernel with sun studio though
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:51): it's neccessary to make such a distinction when you're talking about products of Sun's.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:51): of course, I did hear something about Sun Studio being open sourced awhile back.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:52): (likewise, I also heard something about JES being opened, but that hasn't happened, yet, either)
b8ac460f16efd92d9e259415a4930199 (04:52): well, sun promised to opensource everything so...
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:52): umm, wondering about ldap on Solaris... I know it has a name, sun one or something
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (04:52): Studio cc and dbx are based on pcc and... well, dbx, aren't they? (long long in the past)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:52): skipp_OSX: Sun ONE Directory Server
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (04:52): Take pcc from one of the berkeley distributions, and take the code forward.
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:52): that's the ticket
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (04:52): it'll be fun! :)
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:53): is that something that comes with OpenSolaris?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:53): is that the original C reference compiler?
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:53): yeah, I didn't think so
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:53): it's a part of Sun's JES suite. (suite being redundant)
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:53): is it cheaper than eDirectory on Suse?
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (04:53): delewis: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_C_Compiler
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:54): skipp_OSX: it is free for commercial and non-commercial usage.
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:54): oh, well, that is cheaper =P
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:54): just not open, as such, and you're not entitled to "official" support from Sun, unless you buy a support contract.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:55): ah, so it is the "reference" compiler I was thinking about.
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:55): I am just trying to find something to replace nis and I don't like openldap
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:55): skipp_OSX: Sun ONE Directory Server rocks :-)
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:56): well, I'll check it out
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:56): my main concern is that it passes the KISS test
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:56): I've deployed it for serveral clients and haven't really had a problem with it.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:57): skipp_OSX: unless you're familiar with LDAP, it'll probably fail the KISS test.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:57): LDAP is simple if you sit down and read some documentation on it, but all of the terminology, and thus, how it works will be foreign to you if you don't.
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:57): delewis: I am not familiar with ldap other than I setup openldap briefly
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (04:58): delewis: well, there doesn't seem to be anything else
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:58): skipp_OSX: let me point you towards some documentation on it then
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:58): it'll be most advantageous for you to read it before using Sun ONE Directory Server
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:58): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ldap
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:58): and there's a decent IBM redbook around about it
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (04:59): http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/sg247165.html?Open
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:00): yes, I know the title has "AIX" in it, but it still gives a very "applied" perspective of LDAP, such as how the various LDAP tools work (ldapaddent, etc.)
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (05:01): ok, well, I won't be using any AIX, but the network is unfortunately... cross-platform
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:01): just skip over the parts that are AIX-specific, and you'll still find that redbook worthwhile.
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (05:02): ok, I am looking through it
f4e955839438eceb25b2c1de4257cd77 (05:04): I assume the lessons learned in the redbook will apply to openldap as well as Sun One... correct?

30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:23): movement: I nearly suspected that much - I guess it's because iconv considers the buffer to be too small. but somehow glibc manages to do that..
bc2fbb38d8766b9e1aa476f2ac16b945 (05:23): yes, it must be E2BIG
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (05:24): oxygene: do you try to use GNU libiconv ?
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:24): don't have that installed
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:25): movement: well, ucs4 is 4 bytes wide. passing a single latin1 char in it shouldn't be a problem with a 4byte buffer
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (05:26): oxygene: did you count the termination byte, too ?
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (05:26): oxygene: and in some cases you have a byte order identifier in unicode, too.
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:26): yes, and that seems to be the difference: glibc doesn't send the byte order identifier

30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:34): movement: fread returns the number of read characters. that's passed in num. the result of this assigment operation (which is the value of the assignment) is added to ileft. which is compared "> 0". I see nothing wrong
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:34): hmm i bet that is  nacho (not your) heart.
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:36): movement: also most of the code is taken from the example in iconv(3C) (also slightly buggy btw: there's a "left =" which should be "oleft =")
bc2fbb38d8766b9e1aa476f2ac16b945 (05:37): oxygene: you're asking for BUFSIZE - ileft items of size 1
bc2fbb38d8766b9e1aa476f2ac16b945 (05:37): oxygene: so you'll get more than one
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:37): (and yes, echo foo results in ileft=4 - printf a| is ileft=1 and still hangs in the loop)
bc2fbb38d8766b9e1aa476f2ac16b945 (05:38): (and then adding it to ileft will increase ileft each time)
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:38): sorry, forget to say that
bc2fbb38d8766b9e1aa476f2ac16b945 (05:38): it does indeed but the code is wrong as is already.
bc2fbb38d8766b9e1aa476f2ac16b945 (05:38): and if iconv's example is broken please file a bug
bc2fbb38d8766b9e1aa476f2ac16b945 (05:39): there's no "left =" on my version
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (05:41): uh, am I crazy? *looks*
